awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: Collaborative Research: Ocean Salinity as a predictor of US hydroclimate extremes
awd_abstract_narration:
Water availability is a fundamental necessity for society. As the largest moisture reservoir and ultimate moisture source, water from the oceans sustains terrestrial precipitation and is thus key to understanding variability in the water cycle on land. Floods and droughts represent extremes of the water cycle that have enormous consequences for society. In recent years Western drought has led to billions of dollars of agricultural losses and extensive wildfires, while floods produced similar losses in the South, Midwest and East of the US. They are caused by an excess or deficit of moisture exported from ocean to land.  Moisture evaporating from the ocean surface is the ultimate source for terrestrial precipitation. Thus, the availability of the oceanic moisture supply modulates the severity of hydroclimate extremes on land. As moisture exits the ocean, it leaves a signature in sea surface salinity. Recent studies have provided remarkable new evidence that salinity can be utilized as a skillful predictor of precipitation in the US Midwest, Southwest and other regions. The salinity precursors significantly outperform temperature-based predictors, especially in the years with heavy precipitation or exceptional drought.  Thus, sea surface salinity has great potential to provide a transformative improvement to seasonal forecasts of US hydroclimate extremes. This project will develop the scientific basis for a drought and flood early warning system for the US based on these new insights into the predictive potential of ocean salinity and the expanding salinity monitoring system that uses both in-situ measurements and satellites. This will lead to a number of societal benefits: lives saved and property preserved from wildfires and floods; improved crop yields resulting from more accurate seasonal rainfall forecasts; national security advances realized by better anticipation of destabilized regions affected by drought or flood crises; and more accurate forecasting of energy demand and the impact of water shortages on power plants. Several undergraduate students will have the opportunity to gain valuable research experience, and thus the project will help to train the next generation of climate scientists. Project findings will also be incorporated into graduate courses taught through the MIT/WHOI joint program and at Duke University, and the knowledge will be disseminated to the general public. 

The processes that produce the newly identified relationships between extreme precipitation and sea surface salinity will be explored. Daily precipitation data and a Bayesian statistical framework will be used to sample the extreme events in the US. Based on the Bayesian inference, the pre-season salinity precursors will be explored and mechanisms by which the water cycle generates the salinity signatures determined by calculating atmospheric moisture fluxes and the terms in the surface salinity budget. In addition, the oceanic moisture flux onto land will be tracked, and the processes assessed by which extremes develop through the moisture supply and/or energy redistribution in the atmospheric column. Machine-learning algorithms to predict extremes using the sea surface salinity precursors will be developed and applied. Novel approaches will be used in this project, including the use of Bayesian statistics to identify the optimal sea surface salinity and temperature predictors for rainfall extremes, analysis of the oceanic salinity budget to identify the driving atmospheric variables, analysis of the atmospheric circulations that transport water from ocean to land, and the development of machine learning algorithms to provide optimal seasonal predictions of extreme drought or floods.

por.por_cntn:
Floods and droughts represent extremes of the water cycle that have enormous consequences for society. In the project, Bayesian statistical models were developed to objectively identify extreme rainfall events and to quantify the influence of the large-scale environmental factors. The Bayesian models suggest that extreme rainfall is not only associated with day-to-day weather patterns, but also modulates the variability of regional hydroclimate. The extreme rainfall events can hardly be sustained by moisture from local sources, and thus moisture supplies from remote oceanic sources becomes indispensable. Moisture tracking analysis confirms that extreme rainfall on land is usually accompanied by expanded oceanic water sources and increased oceanic moisture export. 

The oceanic moisture export leaves an imprint on sea surface salinity (SSS), making SSS a nature’s rain gauge. We utilized the rain gauge idea to explore the predictive skills of terrestrial precipitation from preseason SSS. From our analysis, SSS in the moisture export regions could be a skillful predictor for post-season precipitation in the Southwest US, US Midwest, and the Yangtze River Valley in China. The SSS-based predictions outperform those based on SSTs which are currently relied on for seasonal forecast of rainfall. From the analysis of atmospheric circulation dynamics and land-atmosphere interaction, we found the delay mechanisms that bridges the time lag between pre-season salinity and precipitation are through the tropical-extratropical teleconnection and a positive coupling with local soil moisture. The predictive value from SSS becomes more significant as the oceanic water cycle intensifies, and the oceanic moisture constitutes a larger portion of water supply for terrestrial precipitation.

Based on the results from exploratory data analysis, a US rainfall prediction framework was built. Depends on location and lead time, the framework selects the optimal SSTA- and/or SSSA-based predictors for rainfall prediction. Overall, SSTA-based predictors are most skillful at short lead-time, while the SSSA-based predictor are more skillful at a long-lead time (beyond 3-6 months). Thus, the newly developed framework that includes SSSA-based predictor could substantially improve seasonal prediction of precipitation for the US.

The results from the project have been disseminated to the communities of interest by scholarly articles (6 published, 1 under revision, and 4 in preparation), conference presentations (7 including 1 invited talk), 4 seminars in other institutions, and 1 public talk to the non-science staff in the Institute of Computer and Data Science at PSU. The statistical models developed in this project have been made available for public access. Through the project, the PI is currently mentor 2 graduate students from underrepresented groups at PSU's Meteorology program. One REU summer fellow was mentored by the PI in the summer of 2021. In addition, the results from the project have been integrated to undergraduate courses taught at Duke University (EOS202 Ocean and Atmospheric Dynamics) and PSU (METEO421 Atmospheric Dynamics, METEO470 Climate Dynamics, METEO497.2 Hydrometeorology).
